senses.sense: In the state of being active, functioning or operating.
examples: All the lights are on, so they must be home.

senses.sense: Performing according to schedule; taking place.
examples: Are we still on for tonight?
Is the show still on?
We had to ration our food because there was a war on.
That TV programme that you wanted to watch is on now.

senses.sense: Fitted; covering; being worn.
examples: Your feet will soon warm up once your socks are on.
I was trying to drink out of the bottle while the top was still on!

senses.sense: (postpositive) Of a stated part of something, oriented towards the viewer or other specified direction.
examples: The photograph shows the UFO side on.
edge on, side on, end on, face on

senses.sense: (chiefly UK, informal, usually negative) Acceptable, appropriate.
examples: You can't do that; it's just not on.

senses.sense: (informal) Destined, normally in the context of a challenge being accepted; involved, doomed.
examples: "Five bucks says the Cavs win tonight." ―"You're on!"
Mike just threw coffee onto Paul's lap. It's on now.

senses.sense: (baseball, informal) Having reached a base as a runner and being positioned there, awaiting further action from a subsequent batter.
(cricket) Within the half of the field on the same side as the batsman's legs; the left side for a right-handed batsman.
examples: The captain moved two fielders to the on side.
Ponsonby-Smythe hit a thumping on drive.

senses.sense: (acting, drama, RPG) Acting in character.
(euphemistic) Menstruating.
(informal, of a person) Performative or funny in a wearying manner.
examples: He always has to be on, it's so exhausting.

senses.sense: To an operating state.
examples: turn the television on

senses.sense: So as to cover or be fitted.
examples: The lid wasn't screwed on properly.
Put on your hat and gloves.

senses.sense: Along, forwards (continuing an action).
examples: drive on, rock on

senses.sense: In continuation, at length.
examples: and so on
He rambled on and on.

senses.sense: (obsolete in the US) Later.
examples: Ten years on, nothing had changed in the village.

senses.sense: Of betting odds, denoting a better-than-even chance. See also odds-on.
examples: That horse is twenty-to-one on, so you need to stake twenty pounds just to win one pound.

senses.sense: Positioned at the upper surface of, touching from above.
examples: A vase of flowers stood on the table.
Please lie down on the couch.
The parrot was sitting on Jim's shoulder.

senses.sense: Positioned at or resting against the outer surface of; attached to.
examples: He had a scar on the side of his face.
There is a dirty smudge on this window.
The painting hangs on the wall.
The fruit ripened on the trees.

senses.sense: Expressing figurative placement or attachment.
examples: All of the responsibility is on him.
I put a bet on the winning horse.

senses.sense: Denoting performance or action by contact with the surface, upper part, or outside of anything; hence, by means of; with.
examples: to play on a violin or piano

senses.sense: At or in (a certain region or location).
examples: The lighthouse that you can see is on the mainland.
The suspect is thought to still be on the campus.

senses.sense: Near; adjacent to; alongside.
examples: The fleet is on the American coast.
Croton-on-Hudson, Rostov-on-Don, Southend-on-Sea

senses.sense: Supported by (the specified part of itself).
examples: A table can't stand on two legs.
After resting on his elbows, he stood on his toes, then walked on his heels.

senses.sense: So as to impart force to.
examples: tug on the rope; push hard on the door

senses.sense: So as to impact; against.
examples: I stubbed my toe on an old tree stump.

senses.sense: Covering.
examples: He wore old shoes on his feet.

senses.sense: (with certain modes of transport, especially public transport) Inside (a vehicle) for the purpose of travelling.
examples: on a bus, on a train, on a plane

senses.sense: At the date of.
examples: Born on the 4th of July.

senses.sense: Some time during the day of.
examples: On Sunday I'm busy. I'll see you on Monday.
Can I see you on a different day?

senses.sense: At a given time after the start of something; at.
examples: Smith scored again on twelve minutes, doubling Mudchester Rovers' lead.
I'll see you a week on Friday.

senses.sense: Dealing with the subject of; about; concerning.
examples: I was reading a book on history.
The city hosted the World Summit on the Information Society
I have no opinion on this subject.

senses.sense: (informal) In the possession of.
examples: I haven't got any money on me.

senses.sense: Because of, or due to.
examples: to arrest someone on suspicion of bribery
to contact someone on a hunch

senses.sense: Upon; at the time of (and often because of).
examples: On Jack's entry, William got up to leave.
On the addition of ammonia, a chemical reaction begins.

senses.sense: Paid for by.
examples: The drinks are on me tonight, boys.
The meal is on the house.
I paid for the airfare and meals for my family, but the hotel room was on the company.

senses.sense: Indicating a means or medium.
examples: I saw it on television.
Can't you see I'm on the phone?
My favorite shows are on BBC America.
The Beatles' appearance on the Ed Sullivan Show is on YouTube.
The film was released on DVD.

senses.sense: Indicating the target of, or thing affected by, an event or action.
examples: They planned an attack on London.
The soldiers mutinied and turned their guns on their officers.
Her words made a lasting impression on my mind.
What will be the effect on morale?

senses.sense: Toward; for; indicating the object of an emotion.
examples: Have pity or compassion on him.

senses.sense: (especially Ireland) Indicating the person experiencing an emotion, cold, thirst, hunger, etc.
Indicating a means of subsistence.
examples: They lived on ten dollars a week.
The dog survived three weeks on rainwater.

senses.sense: Engaged in or occupied with (an action or activity).
examples: He's on his lunch break.
I'm on nights all this week.
on vacation; on holiday; on the job; on the fiddle

senses.sense: Regularly taking (a drug).
examples: You've been on these antidepressants far too long.
He's acting so strangely, I think he must be on something.

senses.sense: Under the influence of (a drug).
examples: He's acting crazy because he's on crack right now.

senses.sense: (mathematics) Having identical domain and codomain.
examples: a function on

senses.sense: (mathematics) Having <math>V^n</math> as domain and V as codomain, for some set V and integer n.
examples: an operator on

senses.sense: (mathematics) Generated by.
examples: the free group on four letters

senses.sense: In addition to; besides; indicating multiplication or succession in a series.
examples: heaps on heaps of food
mischief on mischief; loss on loss

senses.sense: (obsolete, regional) of
Indicating dependence or reliance.
examples: I depended on them for assistance.
He will promise on certain conditions.

senses.sense: (obsolete) At the peril of, or for the safety of.
Serving as a member of.
examples: He is on the jury; I am on the committee.

senses.sense: By virtue of; with the pledge of.
examples: He affirmed or promised on his word, or on his honour.

senses.sense: To the account or detriment of; denoting imprecation or invocation, or coming to, falling, or resting upon.
examples: On us be all the blame.
A curse on him!
Please don't tell on her and get her in trouble.
He turned on her and has been her enemy ever since.
He went all honest on me, making me listen to his confession.

senses.sense: (especially when numbers of combatants or competitors are specified) Against; in opposition to.
examples: The fight was three on one, and he never stood a chance.

senses.sense: (Singapore, Philippines, Malaysia, transitive, colloquial) To switch on.
examples: Can you on the light?

senses.sense: (UK dialectal, Scotland) Without.
In the Japanese language, a pronunciation, or reading, of a kanji character that was originally based on the character's pronunciation in Chinese, contrasted with kun.
examples: Most kanji have two kinds of reading, called "on" and "kun".

senses.sense: The Asiatic wild ass or hemione (Equus hemionus), an animal of the horse family native to Asia; specifically, the Persian onager, Persian wild ass, or Persian zebra (Equus hemionus onager).

(military, historical) A military engine acting like a sling which threw stones from a bag or wooden bucket powered by the torsion from a bundle of ropes or sinews operated by machinery; a torsion catapult.
examples: , trebuchet

senses.sense: plural of onager
(botany) Of or relating to the family Onagraceae of flowering plants, including the fuchsia and the evening primrose.
plural of onager
Masturbation.
Ejaculating outside the vagina during intercourse; (the performing of) coitus interruptus.
plural of onanism
A person, especially a man, who masturbates.
A man who uses coitus interruptus as a means of birth control.
Of or pertaining to masturbation (onanism).
In a manner which suggests masturbation; hence, fruitless, self-congratulatory, self-absorbed, pointless.
plural of onanist
Carried or used on or in a vehicle or vessel
(by extension, figurative) Being a part of, being included in, participating in
examples: When it comes to security, everybody seems to be as onboard as I am.
James is onboard as a production manager.

senses.sense: On or in a vehicle or vessel; aboard; on board.
(figurative) To become a part of a group; to incorporate (someone) into a group.
(figurative) To begin to use a product or service; to take (someone) on as a new customer of a product or service.
(frequency) One and only one time.
examples: I have only once eaten pizza.

senses.sense: (temporal location) Formerly; during some period in the past.
examples: He was once the most handsome man around.
I once had a bicycle just like that one.
Wang notes that flowers have rooted and grow in the area once covered with ice.

senses.sense: (mostly obsolete) At any time; ever.
examples: If the facts once became known, we'd be in trouble.

senses.sense: (obsolete) One day, someday.
(mathematics) Multiplied by one: indicating that a number is multiplied by one.
examples: Once three is three.

senses.sense: As soon as; when; after.
examples: We'll get a move on once we find the damn car keys!
Once you have obtained the elven bow, return to the troll bridge and trade it for the sleeping potion.
Once he is married, he will be able to claim the inheritance.

senses.sense: Obsolete form of ounce.
(informal, historical) A one-pound note.
(poetic) A person who does something once.
(informal) A single sexual encounter between two individuals, a one-night stand.
(informal) A person with whom one shares a single sexual encounter, a one-night stand.
plural of once
(Southern US, South Midland US, uncommon) Once.
(pathology) A disease caused by a worm of the genus Onchocerca, especially as transmitted to humans by flies and often causing blindness; common in tropical Africa.
Synonym of onchocerciasis
(botany) Any of the genus Oncidium of tropical orchidaceous plants.
plural of oncidium
(medicine) The formation and development of tumors.
Causing the formation of tumors.
examples: oncogenic viruses

senses.sense: Caused by tumors: tumor-induced.
examples: oncogenic osteomalacia

senses.sense: The state or degree of being oncogenic.
An instrument for registering the changes observable with an oncometer.
(oncology) Of or pertaining to oncology
(oncology) Of or pertaining to oncology.
plural of oncology
(oncology) A doctor or scientist who specializes in oncology.
The branch of medicine concerned with tumors, including study of their development, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.
(intransitive, rare) To arrive; come to; come on.
Advent, arrival, approach; onset
The commencement or initial stages of a business, especially of one which requires great exertion.
The setting about of an action; development; progress.
An attack; an attack or onset of a disease, fit, or episode.
(dialectal) A mysterious disease or ailment.
(dialectal) A heavy fall of rain or snow; cloudburst.
(of a chimney) The lower edge of a fire-clay lining piece.
(physiology) An instrument for measuring the variations in size of the internal organs of the body.
Relating to oncometry.
Approach, onset
approaching; coming closer
examples: Look carefully before pulling out into oncoming traffic.

senses.sense: present participle of oncome
plural of oncoming
A device for measuring the specific gravity of a molten metal by recording on a band of paper the sinking or floating effect of a ball of the solid metal immersed in it.
ischemic cell death: a process characterized by mitochondrial swelling, cytoplasm vacuolization, and swelling of the nucleus and cytoplasm
An embryonic form of a tapeworm, enclosed in a spherical membrane armed with six hooks
Additional costs; extra expenses.
(finance) Overhead (expense)
(coal-mining) The cost of upkeep, making and maintaining shafts, roads, pumping, etc.
(UK dialectal, Scotland) The indirect expenditure incurred for the purpose of increasing the productive power of organised labour.
(mining, historical) Any workman who was paid a daily rate.
Relating to osmotic pressure caused by the presence of colloids.
(surgery) The opening of an abscess, or the removal of a tumour, with a cutting instrument.
(chiefly US, Canada) The muskrat.
Alternative form of undine ("water-sprite")
Breathing; smelling.
(UK dialectal) A heavy, continuous fall of rain or snow; a downpour.
The recording produced by an ondograph.
plural of ondogram
An instrument for autographically recording the waveforms of varying currents, especially rapidly varying alternating currents.
An instrument designed to measure wavelengths.
(physics) An instrument that detects (and visualizes) the presence of high-frequency radiation
(arts) wavy; having the surface marked by waves or slightly depressed furrows
examples: ondoyant glass

senses.sense: The number represented by the Arabic numeral 1; the numerical value equal to that cardinal number.
examples: In some religions, there is only one god.
In many cultures, a baby turns one year old a year after its birth.
One person, one vote.

senses.sense: (number theory) The first positive number in the set of natural numbers.
(set theory) The cardinality of the smallest nonempty set.
(mathematics) The ordinality of an element which has no predecessor, usually called first or number one.
(impersonal pronoun, indefinite) One thing (among a group of others); one member of a group.
examples: Any one of the boys.  The big one looks good.  I want the green one.  Every one of the bank’s employees.  A good driver is one who drives carefully.

senses.sense: (impersonal pronoun, sometimes with "the") The first mentioned of two things or people, as opposed to the other.
examples: She offered him an apple and an orange; he took one and left the other.

senses.sense: (indefinite personal pronoun) Any person (applying to people in general).
examples: One’s guilt may trouble one, but it is best not to let oneself be troubled by things which cannot be changed.  One shouldn’t be too quick to judge.

senses.sense: (pronoun) Any person, entity or thing.
examples: "driver", noun: one who drives.

senses.sense: The digit or figure 1.
(mathematics) The neutral element with respect to multiplication in a ring.
(US) A one-dollar bill.
One o'clock, either a.m. or p.m.
(cricket) One run scored by hitting the ball and running between the wickets; a single.
A joke or amusing anecdote.
examples: Did you hear the one about the agnostic dyslexic insomniac?

senses.sense: (colloquial) A particularly special or compatible person or thing.
examples: I knew as soon I met him that John was the one for me and we were married within a month.
That car's the one — I'll buy it.

senses.sense: (dated) (euphemism or derogatory) A gay person.
(Internet slang, leet, sarcastic) Used instead of ! to amplify an exclamation, parodying unskilled typists who forget to press the shift key while typing exclamation points, thus typing "1".
examples: A: SUM1 Hl3p ME im alwyz L0ziN!1!?1! ― Someone help me; I'm always losing!?
B: y d0nt u just g0 away l0zer!!1!!one!!one!!eleven!!1! ― Why don't you just go away loser!

senses.sense: Of a period of time, being particular.
examples: One day the prince set forth to kill the dragon that had brought terror to his father’s kingdom for centuries.

senses.sense: Being a single, unspecified thing; a; any.
examples: My aunt used to say, "One day is just like the other."

senses.sense: Sole, only.
examples: He is the one man who can help you.
The one male audience member at the concert is invited on stage.

senses.sense: Whole, entire.
examples: Body and soul are not separate; they are one.

senses.sense: In agreement.
examples: We are one on the importance of learning.

senses.sense: The same.
examples: The two types look very different, but are one species.

senses.sense: Being a preeminent example.
examples: He is one hell of a guy.

senses.sense: Being an unknown person with the specified name; see also "a certain".
examples: The town records from 1843 showed the overnight incarceration of one “A. Lincoln”.

senses.sense: To cause to become one; to gather into a single whole; to unite.
Used at the end of a sentence to highlight the characteristics of someone or something.
examples: Got almonds one. ― There are almonds in it.
How come so heavy one? ― Why is it so heavy?

senses.sense: Used to emphasize or explain something without specifying the direct object.
examples: My friend in Germany send one. ― It was sent by my friend in Germany.
She tell me one. ― She told me.
Who say one? ― Who said so?

senses.sense: A nominalizer; used to form a noun phrase without a head noun.
examples: The play chess one. ― The one who plays chess.

senses.sense: (relative) Functions as a relative pronoun at the end of a relative clause.
Paris quadrifolia, herb Paris.
Constituting or being indicative of a single aspect or theme.
Consisting of a single undivided part; whole; complete.
Simple, plain, straightforward.
Singular, as opposite to plural.
The property of being onefold.
(mineral) A form of amethyst having hair-like inclusions of goethite
Unity; agreement.
Of or pertaining to dreams.
Resembling a dream; dreamlike.
Synonym of oneirocritic ("an interpreter of dreams")
An interpreter of dreams.
Of or relating to the interpretation of dreams.
Of or relating to the interpretation of dreams.
examples: oneirocritical literature

senses.sense: In terms of dream interpretation.
The art of interpreting dreams.
plural of oneirocritic
The art of interpreting dreams; oneirocriticism.
A violent or disturbed imagination during sleep, as in the case of nightmares and sleepwalking.
An interpreter of dreams.
The study of dreams and their interpretation.
One who practises oneiromancy.
(uncountable, divination) Divination by the interpretation of dreams.
(uncountable, in a weak sense) The interpretation of dreams.
(countable, divination) An act of such divination or dream-interpretation.
Relating to the interpretation of dreams.
One who interprets dreams.
The interpretation of dreams.
Of or relating to oneirosis.
(obsolete) The state of being at one or reconciled.
(uncountable) State of being one or undivided; unity.
(countable) The product of being one or undivided.
plural of oneness
(informal) An extraordinary individual.
A small marble of little worth in children's games.
(UK) A conker that has won one match.
(film production) A long one-take shot, or equivalent animated segment simulating a one-take shot
Fitted for, or carrying, a burden.
(obsolete) To load; to burden.
comparative form of onery: more onery
superlative form of onery: most onery
(rare) Onerousness.
(Scotland, legal) The legal state of affairs resulting from being done or given in return for receipt of something of value.
imposing or constituting a physical, mental, or figurative load which can be borne only with effort; burdensome.
In an onerous manner.
The state or characteristic of being onerous.
(US, particularly, Southern US) Pronunciation spelling of ornery.
plural of one
(sports) A senior or first team (as opposed to a reserves team).
(UK, prison slang) The cells located on the ground floor.
plural of one
Obsolete form of one's.
A person's self: general form of himself, herself, themself or yourself.
examples: Teaching oneself to swim can be dangerous.

senses.sense: Alternative form of one-time ("former; past")
Alternative form of one-time ("occurring once")
Alternative spelling of one-upmanship
A falling on or upon; an attack, onset, or assault.
A fall of rain or snow.
The fall of the evening.
(transitive) To fall on or upon.
(transitive) To assault, attack.
A flowing onward.
flowing onward
Continuing, permanent, lasting.
Presently or currently happening; being in progress.
Something that is going on; a happening.
(rare) present participle of ongo
That which, or one who, hangs on to, relies on, or is dependent upon another; a dependent.
A Japanese evil spirit or demon.
A variety of onyx for cameos, a bluish-white band on the dark ground.
(psychology) An abnormal impulse to buy things, or a condition characterised by such impulses.
A sufferer from oniomania.
A monocotyledonous plant (Allium cepa), allied to garlic, used as vegetable and spice.
The bulb of such a plant.
A plant of the genus Allium as a whole.
(slang, of a drug) An ounce.
(obsolete baseball slang) A ball.
(obsolete, slang) A watch-seal.
Alternative letter-case form of Onion ("an inhabitant of Bermuda; a Bermudian")
(rare, archaic) A small onion.
(informal, rare) Flavoured with, or converted into, onion; made oniony.
Resembling or characteristic of an onion, for example in shape, flavour, or layered structure.
plural of onion
A thin, strong, light, translucent paper; used especially for making carbon copies.
plural of onionskin
Resembling an onion or onions, especially in terms of smell.
Flavoured with onions.
Resembling the satirical news website The Onion.
(of an insect larva) flattened and broad in form

simple past tense and past participle of onlay

(geology) To form an onlap.
(transitive, literary) To lay or place something on a surface.

present participle of onlay
(informal and dialectal) superlative form of only: most only, used to mean "only" but with added intensiveness or emphasis.
examples: I can't stand that bastard there...
* You ain't the onliest one. I can't either.

senses.sense: Of a system: connected (generally electrically) to a larger network.
Of a generator or power plant: connected to the grid.
Of a computer: actively connected to the Internet or to some other communications service.
examples: Is this modem online?

senses.sense: Available over, or delivered from, the Internet.
examples: I prefer to read online newspapers.

senses.sense: Connected to the Internet.
examples: I'll be online tonight, so I'll be able to reply to your email.

senses.sense: Available on a computer system, even if not networked.
examples: Press the F1 key to access the online help.
The program comes with an online manual, supplied on compact disc.

senses.sense: Of a system: active, particularly building facilities (such as power) or a factory or power plant.
examples: The power is online.
Once this factory comes online, it will double car production in our country!

senses.sense: (slang) Immersed in Internet culture. (Usually modified by an intensifier such as extremely or terminally)
While online; while in a running or active state, or connected to the Internet.
examples: He works online.

senses.sense: (computing, transitive) To bring (a system, etc.) online; to promote to an active or running state.
(archaic) The state of being alone or unique.
The act of looking on (something); observation.
That which is looked at, regarded, or considered.
(rare) One's perspective or outlook.
(intransitive) To look on or look at; watch; observe; view; regard.
A spectator; someone looks on or watches, without becoming involved or participating.
examples: I wasn’t involved in the fight; I was only an onlooker.

senses.sense: plural of onlooker
That is looking on; watching, observing.
Alone in a category.
examples: He is the only doctor for miles.
The only people in the stadium were the fans: no players, coaches, or officials.
He was the only male in attendance at the boyband concert.
That was the only time I went to Turkey.

senses.sense: Singularly superior; the best.
Without sibling; without a sibling of the same gender.
examples: He is their only son, in fact, an only child.

senses.sense: (obsolete) Mere.
Without others or anything further; exclusively.
examples: My heart is hers, and hers only.
The cat sat only on the mat. It kept off the sofa.

senses.sense: No more than; just.
examples: The cat only sat on the mat. It didn't scratch it.
If there were only one more ticket!

senses.sense: As recently as.
examples: He left only moments ago.

senses.sense: (Britain) Used to express surprise or consternation at an action.
examples: She's only gone and run off with the milkman!

senses.sense: Introduces a disappointing or surprising outcome that renders futile something previously mentioned.
examples: They rallied from a three-goal deficit only to lose in the final two minutes of play.
I helped him out only for him to betray me.

senses.sense: (obsolete) Above all others; particularly.
(informal) Under the condition that; but.
examples: You're welcome to borrow my bicycle, only please take care of it.

senses.sense: But; except.
examples: I would enjoy running, only I have this broken leg.
She would get good results only she gets nervous.

senses.sense: An only child.
Abbreviation of or nearest offer.
examples: Bike for sale: €300 ono

senses.sense: (Internet, slang) Abbreviation of over and out.
(Hawaiian, slang) good-tasting, delicious.
A centaur with the body of an ass, instead of a prototypical horse.
Worship of the ass or donkey.
Preoccupation with or devotion to something foolish.
divination by the letters of a name; nomancy
Of or pertaining to onomasiology.
(linguistics) A branch of lexicology concerned with the names of concepts.
Of or relating to a personal or place name.
Of or relating to onomastics.
A book, list, or vocabulary of names, especially of people.
examples: We looked up the origin of her name in an onomasticon.

senses.sense: The branch of lexicology devoted to the study of names and naming, especially the origins of names.
Relating to onomatology, the study of the origins of names.
In terms of or by means of onomatology.
One versed in the history of names.
The study of the origins of names; onomastics.

An abnormal obsession with a particular word.
(linguistics) A word formed by onomatopoeia or mimesis
(rare) The fear of hearing particular names or words.
(uncountable) The property of a word of sounding like what it represents.
(countable) A word that sounds like what it represents, such as "gurgle," "stutter," or "hiss".
(countable) A word that appropriates a sound for another sensation or a perceived nature, such as "thud", "beep", or "meow"; an ideophone, phenomime.
(uncountable, rhetoric) The use of language whose sound imitates that which it names.
(obsolete, rare) Of or pertaining to onomatopoeia.
(obsolete) A word formed by onomatopoeia.

Having the property of onomatopoeia.

In an onomatopoeic manner.
onomatopoeia

A forceful rush or flow forward.
An aggressive assault.

To assault aggressively.

rushing or flowing forward
(figuratively) attacking

(archaic) An attack; an assault especially of an army.
(medicine) The initial phase of a disease or condition, in which symptoms first become apparent.
examples: the onset of schizophrenia

senses.sense: (phonology) The initial portion of a syllable, preceding the syllable nucleus.
(acoustics) The beginning of a musical note or other sound, in which the amplitude rises from zero to an initial peak.
A setting about; a beginning.
examples: the onset of puberty

senses.sense: (obsolete) Anything added, such as an ornament or as a useful appendage.
(obsolete) To assault; to set upon.
(obsolete) To set about; to begin.
plural of onset
third-person singular simple present indicative form of onset
(mining, historical, UK, dialect, Northern England) A worker at the bottom of a mineshaft who exchanges the empty and full corves.
(medicine) One who undergoes the onset of a condition.
present participle of onset
(obsolete) onset; beginning
Moving from the sea towards the land.
examples: an onshore breeze

senses.sense: Positioned on or near the shore.
Within the country; not overseas.
From the sea towards the land.
(management) To relocate production, services or jobs to lower-cost locations in the same country.
(sports) Not in an offside position; In the part of the playing area where one can legally play the ball, puck, etc.
examples: The goal was allowed because the attacker was onside.

senses.sense: (by extension, slang) Within bounds.
On the side of a vehicle from which the driver, paddler, etc. propels it.
(bridge) Favourably located, from the point of view of the player taking a finesse.
In agreement or support; on board.
(sport) The portion of the playing area where one can legally play the ball, puck, etc.
The side of a vehicle on which the driver primarily propels it.
(climbing) Without having previously seen the terrain.
(climbing, transitive) To perform a climb without having previously seen the terrain.
A fierce attack.
(by extension) A large number of people or things resembling an attack.
examples: They opened the doors and prepared for the onslaught of holiday shoppers.

senses.sense: plural of onslaught
On the part of a stage that is visible to the audience.
Taking place on the part of a stage that is visible to the audience.
(UK, Scotland, dialect, archaic) A single farmhouse; a steading.
A rapid arrival, especially one that is forceful.
sweeping onward
Ontological.
Pertaining to being generally, as opposed to some theory of it (which would be ontology).
In an ontic sense.
Arriving upon or on top of (speaking of a physical or metaphorical movement).
examples: My cat just jumped onto the keyboard.

senses.sense: (informal) Aware of.
examples: The thought-police were onto my plans of world domination.

senses.sense: (mathematics) Being an onto function with a codomain of (see below).
examples: The exponential function maps the set of real numbers onto the set of positive real numbers.

senses.sense: (mathematics, of a function) Assuming each of the values in its codomain; having its range equal to its codomain.
examples: Considered as a function on the real numbers, the exponential function is not onto.

senses.sense: plural of ontogenesis
The generation and development of an individual organism by the characteristic process of ontogeny associated with its species.
of or relating to ontogenesis
ontogenetic
Synonym of ontogenically
ontogenetic
With regard to ontogeny
plural of ontogeny
ontogenesis
The study of how living creatures react to the physiographic environment.
ontological
Of or relating to ontology.
Of or pertaining to the nature of being or existence.
In an ontological manner.
plural of ontology
Alternative form of ontologize
simple past tense and past participle of ontologise
present participle of ontologise
(philosophy) An ideological system which maintains that God and divine ideas are the first object of our intelligence and the intuition of God's existence the first act of our intellect.
(philosophy) A scholar or theorist of ontology, or an adherent of a particular ontological doctrine.
Of or relating to ontologism.
To convert into ontological entities or express in ontological terms.
(uncountable, philosophy) The branch of metaphysics that addresses the nature or essential characteristics of being and of things that exist; the study of being qua being.

(uncountable, philosophy) In a subject view, or a world view, the set of conceptual or material things or classes of things that are recognised as existing, or are assumed to exist in context, and their interrelations; in a body of theory, the ontology comprises the domain of discourse, the things that are defined as existing, together with whatever emerges from their mutual implications.
(countable, philosophy) The theory of a particular philosopher or school of thought concerning the fundamental types of entity in the universe.
(logic) A logical system involving theory of classes, developed by Stanislaw Lesniewski (1886-1939).
(countable, computer science, information science) A structure of concepts or entities within a domain, organized by relationships; a system model.
(philosophy) A comprehensive explanation for being (in contrast to merely a description of being, or a reason for being).
A legal obligation.
examples: The onus is on the landlord to make sure the walls are protected from mildew.

senses.sense: (legal) Burden of proof, onus probandi.
Stigma.
Blame.
Responsibility; burden.
examples: The onus is on those who disagree with my proposal to explain why.

senses.sense: plural of onus
(not comparable) Moving forward.
examples: There was an onward rush as the gates opened.

senses.sense: Advanced in a forward direction or toward an end.
In a forward direction.
To keep going; to progress or persevere.
onward
Progress; advancement.
onward
third-person singular simple present indicative form of onward
(obsolete) the operculum of kinds of strombus or muricid, smoked as an ingredient in the Mosaic incense and pre-modern medicine
(obsolete) The precious stone onyx.
A whitlow.
An affection of a finger or toe, attended with ulceration at the base of the nail, and terminating in the destruction of the nail.
plural of onychium
Synonym of onychia
A little claw.
thickening and curvature of the nails
(medicine) The loosening or separation of a fingernail or toenail from its bed
An ancient form of divination based on the reflections of sunlight on a boy's fingernails.
Fungal infection of the nail, especially the toenail.
Relating to onychopathy.
The study of diseases of the nails.
A disease of the fingernails or toenails.
(psychopathology) Compulsive biting of one's nails
(rare) A person who bites his or her fingernails.
the habit of biting one's nails
(zoology) Any of many wormlike carnivorous ecdysozoan animals of the phylum Onychophora.
Synonym of onychomadesis

(pathology) fingernail and toenail brittleness and breakage, such as may be due to excessive strong soap and water exposure, nail polish remover, hypothyroidism, anemia, anorexia nervosa or bulimia, or after oral retinoid therapy.
Synonym of onychoschisis
(pathology) Any disease or disorder of the fingernails or toenails.
(rare) The state of being onymous.
Having a name.
(mineral) A banded variety of chalcedony, a cryptocrystalline form of quartz.
A jet-black color, named after the gemstone.
Any of various lycaenid butterflies of the genus Horaga.
jet-black
plural of onyx
Alternative form of onychitis
(historical) A traditional Spanish unit of mass, equivalent to about 28.76 g.
(cryptozoology) A cryptid in Mexican folklore said to be similar to a cougar or jaguarundi but especially aggressive.
